pros: * Able to work fully remote * Invited to Manila (duty travel) * Part of a committed group driving values' work
cons: * Working remote in a different time zone can affect meeting scheduling

pros: Good conditions. Motivating colleagues. Good salary.
cons: Slow staff admin services. Sometimes managers are technically proficient but not necessarily strong in HR management.

pros: Nothing can be nobler than working at the World Health Organization to save lives, promote health and secure the world.
cons: WHO has very few negatives, the most infamous of which is its bureaucracy. As employees, we face long and tedious processes even for simple activities. Fortunately, in the face of emergencies, we tend to be faster by using the “emergency” tag.

review_title: Data and IT specialists are scarce outside IT division
pros: High flexibility of work, including planning and designing the system, and appreciation of specialty from colleagues, partners and supervisors.
cons: Extra effort required to explain system requirements and IT security measures.

pros: Most respected organization in the world
cons: They don't have work life balance

pros: Health Insurance benefit and tax-free salary
cons: Understaffed, less career opportunities if local staff

review_title: An honor to be part of the Organization
pros: People are all warm and approachable. You will get to learn the culture of colleagues from other countries. Updates on health is always available in internal email.
cons: The consultancy is unstable and temporary. The email access and all its content will be removed after the contract ending, even if you will have a contract in another year.

pros: UN benefits - 30 annual leaves, very good health insurance, generous sick leave entitlements, pension scheme
cons: Low regard for Filipinos;  bureaucratic with lots of administrative processes, annual salary increase is very minimal - can reach as high as 0.6% :)

review_title: Overall experience working in WHO was like a roller coaster ride.
pros: Best reasons to work in WHO is for medical benefits and tax exempted salary.
cons: Downside working in WHO is the time spent working beyond the norm due to complexity of the computer system environment installed without proper training for the staff as well as the crab-mentality culture existing among Filipino employees.

job_title: Senior Executive Administrative Assistant in Manila, Manila
pros: Diversity, humanitarian work, global leader in health.  Great health insurance.
cons: Very limited opportunities for promotion.  Huge gap in compensation and benefits between the Professional staff and General Service Staff.  Recruitment is influenced by politics.

pros: Good compensation package even for national/local staff tax free for non-US citizen.
cons: Traditional and hierarchal.  Have no clear stand for national professionals.
